comments.commentBody: Other news organizations are reporting the child was attending a school field trip when he went to get a snack across Northern. At what point is the school responsible for the child's safety, and had the child reached that point? Also when school is in session, there is a crossing guard at that corner.

The staff is small though, so patience is appreciated when fixes need to be made and additions need to be rolled out.

In defense of flight attendants, I find most to be accommodating, not imperious as described in the above comment.  If anything airline employees are as beleaguered by TSA screenings etc. as their irritated passengers.

David,

You've said this before. But basing costs on LCOE only creates a false economy. Nuclear has externalized costs — HUGE externalized costs — that must be part of any valid equation. CSP is free of all, or almost all of those costs.

Additionally, CSP is only more costly now because there is so little of it. But at one time there was just one light bulb on the planet, and it probably cost millions, or at least hundreds of thousands in today's money to develop. Now light bulbs are everywhere and dirt cheap for the service they provide.

Build a few hundred CSP plants and link them together, then power them with FREE, not polluting sunlight. Cost'll go down, waaay down. Far lower than any possible nuclear plant operation could touch.

www.ecotecture.com

What I had heard was that  the restriction against using cells phone in the air was originally at the request of cell phone companies. It was not mainly a safety issue. The network of cell towers was designed to hand-off calls from one cell to another for a car going 65 mph at ground level. In a plane going 700 mph at 35000 feet, one call might occupy one frequency on several cell towers, thus reducing the capacity of the network.

I had to babysit my younger sister when I was around 9 or 10. We physically fought all the time. (She would actually hide behind things and jump out and attack me. That was and is her personality, although thankfully, she now doesn't physically attack anymore.)

One day, she really almost stabbed me with a knife. She was 5 or 6 and really didn't understand the consequences. I parried with a (hard) sofa cushion, which was destroyed.

That is obviously an extreme example, but we should not have been unsupervised with the relationship we had.

Reply to Ross Williams

The US is in a death spiral due to lack of revenue and unless something is done about it, the US is as they say, history.

You write:
"Do we want loose gun regulations, where there is no cohesive nationwide database, so that felons and those with a history of mental illness can never buy weapons?"

Your argument would make more sense if you delete the word "never".

I agree. How can it be that in a Democracy an organization with 4 million members tells CONGRESS and 296+ million citizens what the law of the land will be? THE driving force behind the NRA appears to be lots of money to politicians and money to lobbyist and lawyers for arms manufacturers who can gain access to Congress quicker than the average citizen. Every member of Congress who is a member of the NRA has the blood of Sandy Hook victims and every other massacre on their hands. We must not allow the innocent children and teachers of Sandy Hook to be forgotten. Change must happen. I hope the NY Times will keep up the pressure on every organization and person who supports the NRA to have a change of heart (and mind). We all need to express our opinons to our elected officials and help keep the presssure on them, too.
I find it ironic that the NRA hides behine mental health but never examines their own mental health. What normal mind sees a need for such destructive power? It's smacks of outrageous fear mongering and intimidation, and of organized crime that we haven't seen in many years.

-- “How is it that an organization with 4 million members in a country of over 300 million people has gained such undue influence in government? Each time I read about the machinations of the NRA, I keep asking myself ... why?”

This actually is a great question. The answer is: because, it’s not “undue influence.” Contrary to the liberal favorite fantasies, over 50% of the voters are sympathetic to the NRA, agreeing with its political stance; because contrary to the popular caricatures perpetrated by the media in the Northeast, NRA is not an extremist organization, the numerous misrepresentations of its principles and activities notwithstanding. The 4.3 million of the NRA members are merely financially contributing to the Institute for Legislative Action (NRA-ILA). The canard – common in some quarters -- that it’s allegedly merely the gun makers that are controlling the NRA is just that.

'The bureau, which has been mired in a scandal over Operation Fast and Furious, the botched scheme to investigate gun trafficking across the Mexican border, has been without a permanent full-time director for six years — ever since the National Rifle Association persuaded Congress that the position should require Senate confirmation.'

How is it that an organization with 4 million members in a country of over 300 million people has gained such undue influence in government? Each time I read about the machinations of the NRA, I keep asking myself ... why? This is a group, ever more militant, which has positions which often do not match what the citizens of our great nation want.

Do we want loose gun regulations, where there is no cohesive nationwide database, so that felons and those with a history of mental illness can never buy weapons? Do we want weapons created for war, with small aesthetic differences, with can kill as fast as someone can pull a trigger?

Is the personal satisfaction of a small group of gun owners intent on possessing rapid fire, dangerous weapons worth the life of even one person, let alone the life of a child?

My guess is that if you walk down the aisle of any commercial aircraft with an electromagnetic wave detector, after the request to turn off all such devices, the thing will act like a Geiger counter at Chernobyl.  But since any given passenger is further from potentially sensitive instruments than the pilots, the ban on passenger use of "all devices with an on-off switch" is probably not justified.  As to cell phones, if there is real evidence they can set off blasting caps in mining and construction sites or do some other nasty distant effects, there is at least an argument for banning them in aircraft during flight.

Plenty of us who agree with Mr. Bartlett are concerned about the debt. Many of us would advocate instituting a national health insurance scheme like that in Great Britain and then applying to our debt the 7.6% difference in GDP between what is currently spent in Great Britain and the U.S. on healthcare. Given our $15 trillion GDP, that would allow the debt to be paid down at more than $1.1 trillion/year. Yes, that is a little too simplistic; we would not realize such gains all at once. Surely you can understand this logic, though.

I like this one... I still have a time getting my pistol back together right after a cleaning. If I had S&W instead of metal shop in the 7th grade (sorry Mr. Sims, but I never had another opportunity to bend sheet metal into a box) I'd be ahead of the game today.
Well, as long as I survived the gun toting bullies of Junior high that is.
With the advent of the 3-D printer the manufacturing of a gun (or ammo for that matter) may be easier than you think, and when that time comes, those guns will not set off a metal detector...

I like it but in a few years they're gonna bring the "printing" concept online and then we'll be able to machine our own weapons in the basement out of a solid block of steel using CAD.

How about replacing all science classes (especially earth science and human anatomy!) with extra "shop" courses in which good kids can be taught how to assemble their own assault rifles from scratch and thereby be transformed into good adults.  We will, of course, need to spend a few billion dollars to study the issue first just to ensure that we wouldn't be harming sales.
Well, the Los Angeles part of it wasn't hard, since there is no team in the LA metro area.

I, uh, knew that when I posted it. It's still kind of interesting that the biggest cities are just shut out of the NFL playoffs many years.
(Also, how come the second biggest metro area in the country doesn't have a team for the supposed new "national pastime?")

You know what's interesting?

The four biggest metropolitan areas in the country are already shut out of the playoffs: New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, and Dallas.

Wait till next year...

Amen, amen, amen.

If Coughlin finds a better offensive coordinator because he's given an ultimatum, it will be just the latest example of Coughlin getting credit for discovering talent, where the "discovery" was accidental or forced and completely unrelated to his supposed eye for talent. Victor Cruz? Cut once, and would have been cut again if not for injuries. Stevie Brown? Would have been riding the bench all year if not for injuries. Spagnuolo? Wasn't his first choice. Kevin Boothe (just named by Andy Benoit as one of the league's best guards this year)? Rode the bench for years until departures necessitated his getting a chance.

FIRE GILBRIDE NOW!

Unbelievable, simply unbelievable.  Two identical seasons, one leads to a SB, the other leads to no playoffs.  What's the one single thing that shows week after week?  The single most unimaginative, most predictive offense in the NFL.  Good teams with good defense will always stop the Giants.  Both SB victories under TC were possible because the D stopped a prolific offense, kept the score close and allowed Eli & Co. to make miraculous plays to pull out the wins.  And why?  Kevin Gilbride, the worst offensive mind in the history of the game.  How bad is this guy?  Two SB rings and never a single sniff at another job, no horrible team looking for a new coach has ever even interviewed this guy.  After SB XLII, the Raiders supposedly asked permission to interview him, but immediately denied they were interested. He's a bum, always been a bum, always will be a bum.  Has any other offensive coordinator ever been punched in the face by his fellow defensive coordinator?  On the sideline, during a game?  See Houston Oilers and Buddy Ryan.  The Giants get at least 2-4 wins a season more without KG.  How does he stay employed?  Get rid of this guy.  The Giants owners owe the fans accountability for the pitiful play of this team.  They say you can't fire all the players, so the bottom line is to give TC an ultimatum, change your assistant coaches or lead them out the door looking for a new job.  Two consecutive 9-7 seasons after 6-2 starts is simply unacceptable.  Fire Gilbride, NOW!

Boycott Starbucks?  Would the AARP consider such a thing?  Why not?

Time for Mr. Shultz to understand that ignorance costs money.

Into a cup of hot, black coffee, put one tablespoon of whitner. Next, put in one shake of cinnamon and then two shakes of nutmeg. Stir and let sit for a minute. (Adjust indgredients to taste.) Call it the Fix the Ignorance Latte.

Let's punch up the name a bit. Use low-fat, powdered whitner. Now it's a skinny, dry, Fix the Ignorance Latte.

Spread it around, encourage others to reduce their own spending with it. Encourge them to ask for it at Star Bucks. When the barrista says they don't know that, mention we're even since Mr. Shultz doesn't know economics. Smile nicely.

Don't want to be personal? Mail a copy of Dr. Krugman's column to local Star Bucks. Mention you're enjoying your Fix the Ignorance Latte without Star Bucks until Mr. Shultz fixes his ignorance of our grossly inquitable economy.

Spread it enough and it will make the evening news, as did Shultz's bit of false equivalence. If it does make the TV evening news, it will be a chance for a knowledgeable person to explain to a reporter what is a false equivalence.

Most people aren't attracted to economics but they do pay attention to humor. This is a chance to use humor to drive home an important point Republicans and their fellow travellers keep trying to obscure.
